description: North Korean state-sponsored group known for financial cybercrime, destructive attacks, and espionage operations including the Sony Pictures hack, WannaCry ransomware, and numerous cryptocurrency thefts.

tools.name: WannaCry
tools.description: WannaCry is a ransomware program that encrypts files on infected computers and asks users to pay ransom in Bitcoin to decrypt them. It spread through an exploit in Windows SMBv1 and caused massive disruption to businesses and critical infrastructure worldwide.

tools.name: ThreatNeedle
tools.description: ThreatNeedle is a backdoor that has been used by Lazarus Group since at least 2019 to target cryptocurrency, defense, and mobile gaming organizations. It is considered to be an advanced cluster of Lazarus Group's Manuscrypt (a.k.a. NukeSped) malware family.

tools.name: Dtrack
tools.description: Dtrack is spyware that was discovered in 2019 and has been used against Indian financial institutions, research facilities, and the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant. Dtrack shares similarities with the DarkSeoul campaign, which was attributed to Lazarus Group.

tools.name: RATANKBA
tools.description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group. RATANKBA has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. RATANKBA has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines.

notes.text: We named Lazarus the most active group of 2020
notes.author: Kaspersky ICS CERT

description: North Korean subgroup of Lazarus Group that primarily targets South Korean organizations, particularly in healthcare, government, and financial sectors.

sources.note: Initial identification by South Korean security firm

tools.name: gh0st RAT
tools.description: Gh0st RAT (Remote Access Terminal) is a trojan “Remote Access Tool” used on Windows platforms, and has been used to hack into some of the most sensitive computer networks on Earth.

tools.name: gh0st RAT
tools.description: Rifdoor is a remote access trojan (RAT) that shares numerous code similarities with HotCroissant.

notes.text: Focuses heavily on South Korean government agencies, military organizations, and a variety of domestic companies
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: North Korean subgroup of Lazarus Group specializing in financial institutions and cryptocurrency theft operations.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: DarkComet
tools.description: DarkComet is a remote access tool (RAT) with features including remote shell, file transfer, keylogging, screen and video capture, and remote process control — commonly used to control compromised hosts and collect sensitive data.

tools.name: Net (Windows)
tools.description: The Net utility is a component of the Windows operating system. It is used in command-line operations for control of users, groups, services, and network connections. Net has a great deal of functionality, much of which is useful for an adversary, such as gathering system and network information for Discovery, moving laterally through SMB/Windows Admin Shares using net use commands, and interacting with services.

notes.text: Significant operations include the 2016 Bank of Bangladesh heist, during which APT38 stole $81 million, as well as attacks against Bancomext and Banco de Chile
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Chinese military unit conducting cyber espionage operations primarily targeting intellectual property and sensitive information from various industries.

sources.note: Groundbreaking 2013 report that first publicly attributed this group

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: PoisonIvy
tools.description: PoisonIvy is a remote access trojan (RAT) providing remote shell, file transfer, keylogging, screen capture, and persistence mechanisms; commonly used for interactive control and data exfiltration.

tools.name: PsExec
tools.description: PsExec is a Windows Sysinternals utility used to execute processes on remote systems. Adversaries use it for lateral movement, remote command execution, and service/agent deployment in compromised networks.

notes.text: First APT group to be publicly attributed to specific PLA unit
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Russian military intelligence cyber unit targeting government, military, and security organizations worldwide. This group has been active since at least 2004.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: Responder
tools.description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication.

tools.name: certutil
tools.description: CertUtil.exe is an admin command line tool intended by Microsoft to be used for manipulating certification authority (CA) data and components. This includes verifying certificates and certificate chains, dumping and displaying CA configuration information and configuring Certificate Services. Attackers can use certutil to replace PowerShell for specific tasks such as downloading a file from a remote URL and encoding and decoding a Base64 obfuscated payload.

notes.text: APT28 reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Financially motivated group targeting banks, payment processors, and hospitality companies worldwide. Often confused with separate Carbanak group.

tools.name: AdFind
tools.description: AdFind is a command-line Active Directory query tool that plays a significant role in the ransomware ecosystem, particularly in the reconnaissance phase of a ransomware attack chain. Originally designed for legitimate administrative purposes, AdFind is often leveraged by threat actors to gather critical information about an organization's Active Directory environment. This information is crucial for understanding the network topology, identifying high-value targets, and planning subsequent stages of the attack.

tools.name: Cobalt Strike
tools.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as 'adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors'. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.

tools.name: Carbanak
tools.description: Carbanak is a remote backdoor designed for espionage, data exfiltration, and to remote control.

notes.text: FIN7 may be linked to the Carbanak Group, but there appears to be several groups using Carbanak malware and are therefore tracked separately.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Turla is a Russian state-sponsored cyber espionage group attributed to the FSB. Active since at least 2004, Turla has targeted government, military, educational, and research organizations across more than 50 countries. Known for sophisticated malware, watering hole attacks, and stealthy persistence mechanisms.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history
Detailed analysis of Turla's Epic campaign
US government advisory on Snake malware

tools.name: Kazuar
tools.description: Kazuar is a .NET-based backdoor that supports encrypted command-and-control communications, keylogging, remote shell access, and data exfiltration. It is designed for long-term espionage and stealthy persistence across Windows systems.

tools.name: Snake
tools.description: Snake (also known as Uroburos) is a sophisticated rootkit and cyber espionage platform capable of covert data exfiltration, modular payload delivery, and long-term persistence. It supports multiple operating systems including Windows, Linux, and macOS.

tools.name: Carbon
tools.description: Carbon is a second-stage backdoor designed for lateral movement and remote command execution. It communicates over HTTPS and includes features for system reconnaissance, payload delivery, and command scheduling.

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

notes.text: Turla is known for using watering hole attacks and custom backdoors to compromise military and government targets across more than 50 countries.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: APT32 is a Vietnam-based cyber espionage group active since at least 2014. It targets foreign governments, dissidents, journalists, and private sector industries across Southeast Asia. Known for strategic web compromises, phishing, and custom malware.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history
Targeting of corporate media and private sector

tools.name: Cobalt Strike
tools.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial adversary simulation tool that provides post-exploitation capabilities including command execution, lateral movement, and beaconing.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

notes.text: APT32 has used Cobalt Strike and Mimikatz during large-scale operations targeting Southeast Asian governments and private sector organizations.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: Sidewinder is a cyber espionage group active since at least 2012, suspected to be Indian. It has targeted government, military, and business entities across South Asia, including Pakistan, China, Nepal, and Afghanistan. Known for spear-phishing, malware loaders, and registry-based persistence.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

tools.name: MSHTA
tools.description: MSHTA is a Windows utility used to execute Microsoft HTML Applications (HTA). It can be leveraged by threat actors to run malicious scripts and bypass application control mechanisms.

tools.name: JavaScript
tools.description: JavaScript is a scripting language commonly used in web environments to create interactive content and automate browser-side behaviour. Threat actors may use it to deliver malicious payloads, redirect users, or exploit vulnerabilities in client-side applications.

notes.text: Sidewinder has used PowerShell, MSHTA, and JavaScript to drop and execute malware loaders, often delivered via spear-phishing campaigns targeting South Asian government and military organisations.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: Patchwork is a suspected Indian cyber espionage group active since at least 2015. It has targeted diplomatic, government, and think tank organisations across South and Southeast Asia, often using spear-phishing and custom malware loaders.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history

tools.name: PowerSploit
tools.description: PowerSploit is a modular post-exploitation framework written in PowerShell. It includes scripts for code execution, credential theft, and reconnaissance.

tools.name: QuasarRAT
tools.description: QuasarRAT is a remote access trojan written in .NET that provides keylogging, screen capture, file manipulation, and remote command execution. It is commonly used by threat actors for surveillance and data exfiltration.

tools.name: AutoIt
tools.description: AutoIt is a scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general scripting. It can be compiled into standalone executables and is used by threat actors to deliver and execute payloads.

notes.text: Patchwork has used PowerSploit, QuasarRAT, and AutoIt-based backdoors in spear-phishing campaigns targeting diplomatic and government organisations across South Asia.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: APT33 is a suspected Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group active since at least 2013. It has targeted aerospace, energy, and petrochemical organisations in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea, using spear-phishing, credential theft, and publicly available tools.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history

tools.name: LaZagne
tools.description: LaZagne is an open-source credential recovery tool that extracts passwords from local applications. It supports modules for browsers, databases, and system components, and has been used by threat actors to gather credentials from compromised systems.

tools.name: SniffPass
tools.description: SniffPass is a network traffic sniffer that captures plaintext passwords transmitted over protocols such as HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and POP3. It is used by threat actors to intercept credentials during active sessions.

tools.name: DarkComet
tools.description: DarkComet is a remote administration tool (RAT) with features including remote shell, file transfer, keylogging, screen and video capture, and remote process control — commonly used to control compromised hosts and collect sensitive data.

notes.text: APT33 has used LaZagne, SniffPass, and DarkComet to collect credentials and maintain access to aerospace and petrochemical organisations in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany
